docs.snippet: SENATE SANITARY COMMITTEE.--The Sanitary Committee met at 3 P. M. yesterday in the City Li brary, and listened to a statement from Lieut. EGBERT L. VIELE with regard to the existing evils in the management of the sanitary affairs of the City and...
docs.lead_paragraph: SENATE SANITARY COMMITTEE.--The Sanitary Committee met at 3 P. M. yesterday in the City Li brary, and listened to a statement from Lieut. EGBERT L. VIELE with regard to the existing evils in the management of the sanitary affairs of the City and their remedy. He said the health of a particular locality depended on its topography and not on its latitude.

headline.main: LAW REPORTS.; The Knox Perjury Case. COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS. SUPREME COURT COURT CALENDAR

docs.lead_paragraph: COURT CALENDAR--WEDNESDAY. [The annual Charter election occurring to-day, no Court will be in session.] COMMON PLEAS--Part I,--Nos. 1857, 1994, 1996, 1997, 1609, 795, 2002, 2003, 2004, 2005, 2007, 2008, 2009, 1015, 870. SUPREME COURT--Special Term.--Demurrers--Nos. 21, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 28, 29. Law and Justice-Nos. 41, 42, 43, 44, 45, 48, 49, 50, 51, 52, 53.

headline.main: ANNIVERSARY DINNER OF ST. NICHOLAS SOCIETY.; Speech of Mr. Crittenden.

docs.snippet: CIVIL SIDE. December Term commences to-day at the City Hall, in the Supreme Court, for the First Judicial District of the State of New-York, (composed of New-York City,) in the Superior Court of the City of New-York, and in the Court of Common Pleas...

headline.main: December Term of the Law Courts.

docs.lead_paragraph: CIVIL SIDE. December Term commences to-day at the City Hall, in the Supreme Court, for the First Judicial District of the State of New-York, (composed of New-York City,) in the Superior Court of the City of New-York, and in the Court of Common Pleas for the City and County of New-York. Besides these there are the Marine Court, open every day except Sunday, and the Surrogate's Court, which have no specific Terms.

docs.snippet: Public attention is mainly turned towards Washington. Congress meetsto-day, and our readers are tolerably certain of being able to read the Message to-morrow morning. We are happy to say, moreover, that its length is likely to be somewhat less...
docs.lead_paragraph: Public attention is mainly turned towards Washington. Congress meetsto-day, and our readers are tolerably certain of being able to read the Message to-morrow morning. We are happy to say, moreover, that its length is likely to be somewhat less formidable than was apprehended. Its eighteen columns have dwindled down to ten.

headline.main: A MODEL HUSBAND.; Application of Mrs. Mary A. Bennett for Divorce from Dr. George Bennett. Extraordinary Revelations of Domestie Cruelty and Brutality.

docs.lead_paragraph: We find in the New-Haven papers, the report of the testimony given by Mrs. MARY A. BENNETT, wife of one Dr. GEORGE BENNETT, said to have gained some notoriety and a good deal of money by the manufacture and sale of pills, upon her application for a divorce on the ground of cruel treatment.

docs.snippet: To the Editor of the New-York Times: The people of this misgoverned and overtaxed City are called upon to select on Tuesday next one of three gentlemen now in nomination for the office of Comptroller of the City of New-York-an office more important...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor of the New-York Times: The people of this misgoverned and overtaxed City are called upon to select on Tuesday next one of three gentlemen now in nomination for the office of Comptroller of the City of New-York-an office more important to the various interests of this City than the heads of all the Departments put together.

docs.snippet: The talk of the Clubs and of Westminster Hall this week has been more about Sir JOHN YOUNG'S confidential dispatches, and how they came to be published, than about any other topic which floats upon the surface of attention.

headline.main: The Invention of Anesthesia--National Testimonial to Dr. Wm. T. G. Morton..

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor of the New-York Times: An article appeared in your issue of the 15th, under the caption "Who Invented Anesthesia," which though written in an apparently candid spirit, and with a desire to present to your readers the facts in the history of the discovery of Anesthesia,
